instruction: How were the machine learning models trained and assessed in this study?

The first set consisted of 9 plasma samples spiked with Aspergillus (the target infection) and 7 Aspergillus-free plasma samples. The second set was created by oversampling these 16 samples to generate 200 spectral data points.

Two models were trained using Partial Least Squares-Discriminant Analysis (PLS-DA) on these two sets of data. Additionally, two further models were trained using the same sets of data, but with auto-scaling performed prior to PLS-DA.

instruction: Can infrared spectroscopy, combined with machine learning, be considered a superior diagnostic tool for Invasive Aspergillosis compared to traditional methods, based on the results of this study?
Output: It can be concluded that infrared spectroscopy, combined with machine learning, shows promise as a superior diagnostic tool for Invasive Aspergillosis compared to traditional methods. The study demonstrated that the models trained using infrared spectral data were able to accurately identify Aspergillus species in blood plasma, even in the presence of potential confounders commonly found in patients at risk of Invasive Aspergillosis. The accuracy of the simple model was 84.4%, which improved to 93.3% when oversampling and autoscaling were applied. These results suggest that infrared spectroscopy, in combination with machine learning algorithms, has the potential to provide convenient, efficient, and cost-effective diagnostics for Invasive Aspergillosis.
